<!--https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modality-forms#modality-forms__1-->
<h1>Modality: forms</h1>            <div class="fcdo-s20">from <a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/english-grammar-today/" class="a--rev">English Grammar Today</a></div>
</div><div class="content"><div class="section_anchor" id="modal-verbs"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title">Modal verbs</h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>Core modal verbs have only one form. They have no <i class="i">to</i>-infinitive form, -<i class="i">ing</i> form, past form or -<i class="i">ed</i> form. We have to reword what we want to say by using other expressions:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I’d love to be able to see the Taj Mahal one day.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">I’d love to can see the Taj Mahal one day</s>.</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">They had to sell their house.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">They musted sell their house</s>.</p></blockquote><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Affirmative (+) forms</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>Modal verbs are placed first in the verb phrase (after the subject) and are followed by a verb in the base form. The next verb may be a main verb or an auxiliary verb (<i class="i">be</i>, <i class="i">have</i>):</p><p class="p">Modal verbs do not change form for tense or person. Modal verbs can be followed by the substitute verb <i class="i">do</i>:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">We thought he</i> <b class="b"><i class="i">might</i></b> <i class="i">sell the house</i></p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Yes, he</i> <b class="b"><i class="i">could do</i></b>.</p></div></div></blockquote><p class="p">Modal verbs cannot be used with another modal verb:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Windsurfing <b class="b">can</b> be difficult.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">Windsurfing can might be difficult</s>. or <s class="s">Windsurfing might can be difficult</s>.</p></blockquote><p class="p">Modal verbs always go before other verbs in a verb phrase:</p><p class="p">[in a restaurant after a meal]</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I think the bill <b class="b">could</b> be expensive.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">I think the bill could expensive</s>.</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">You <b class="b">can</b> go swimming, go for a long walk or visit the exhibition.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">You can swimming, go for a long walk or visit the exhibition</s>.</p></blockquote><p class="p">Modal verbs can only be used alone when the main verb is clearly understood:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">She</i> <b class="b"><i class="i">could</i></b> <i class="i">take the bus</i>.</p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Yeah, that’s true. She</i> <b class="b"><i class="i">could</i></b>. (She could take the bus.)</p></div></div></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">He may be wrong, you know</i>.</p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Yes, he</i> <b class="b"><i class="i">may</i></b>. (Yes, he may be wrong.)</p></div></div></blockquote></div></div>      <div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Negative (−) forms</h3></div><div class="content"><div class="panel pad-indent"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title">Warning: </span></div><div class="panel-body pad-indent"><p class="p">Negatives are formed by adding ‘not’ after the modal verbs. We don’t use <i class="i">don’t</i>/<i class="i">doesn’t/didn’t</i> with modal verbs:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We <b class="b"><span class="target"/>can’t</b> hear very well at the back.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">We don’t can hear very well</s> …</p></blockquote></div></div></div></div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Question (?) forms</h3></div><div class="content"><div class="panel pad-indent"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title">Warning: </span></div><div class="panel-body pad-indent"><p class="p">The subject and the modal verb change position to form questions. We don’t use <i class="i">do/does/did</i>:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Could</b> you help me?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">Do you could help me?</s></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Will</b> it be a problem?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">Does it will be a problem?</s></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Why <b class="b">can’t</b> you come too?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">Why don’t you can come too?</s></p></blockquote></div></div><p class="p">We use modal verbs in question tags:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">You <b class="b">can’t</b> live like that, <b class="b">can</b> you?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">It <b class="b">could</b> be any of those things, <b class="b">couldn’t</b> it?</i></p></blockquote><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/tags#tags__3">Question tags </a> </p></li><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/tags">Tags </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div>
<div id='ad_contentslot_1' class='am-default contentslot'>
</div>
<div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Contracted forms</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">In speaking <i class="i">shall</i> and <i class="i">will</i> are often contracted to ’<i class="i">ll</i> and <i class="i">would</i> is contracted to ’<i class="i">d</i>, especially when they follow a pronoun:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I’<b class="b">ll</b> see you later.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We<b class="b">’ll</b> never get there.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I knew they<b class="b">’d</b> love it.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">The negative forms of modal verbs are often contracted.</p><div class="panel"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title"/></div><div class="panel-body"><table class="table"><span class="colgroup"><col class="col"/><col class="col"/><col class="col"/></span><thead class="thead"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">modal verb</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">uncontracted negative</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">contracted negative</p></td></tr></thead><tbody class="tbody"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">can</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">cannot</i> (usually written as one word not two)</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">can’t</i> /kɑnt/</p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">could</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">could not</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">couldn’t</i> /ˈkʊdənt/</p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">may</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">may not</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"/></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">might</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">might not</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">mightn’t</i> /ˈmaɪtənt/</p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">will</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">will not</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">*won’t</i> /wəʊnt/ or <i class="i">’ll not</i></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">shall</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">shall not</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">*shan’t</i> /ʃɑnt/ or <i class="i">’ll not</i></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">would</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">would not</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">*wouldn’t</i> /ˈwʊdənt/ or <i class="i">’</i><i class="i">d not</i></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">should</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">should not</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">shouldn’t</i> /ˈʃʊdənt/</p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">must</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">must not</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">mustn’t</i> /ˈmʌsənt/</p></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><p class="p">* is the more common of the two forms.<span class="target"/></p></div></div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Modal verbs and adverbs</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>We usually put adverbs in mid position between the modal verb and the main verb:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Loud noises may <b class="b">sometimes</b> frighten dogs and other animals.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">You’ll <b class="b">probably</b> notice something different about the house.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">When the main verb is understood, we can put the adverb between the subject and the modal verb:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">I can</i> <b class="b"><i class="i">never</i></b> <i class="i">remember Flo’s number</i>.</p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">I</i> <b class="b"><i class="i">never</i></b> <i class="i">can either</i>. (I can never remember Flo’s number either.)</p></div></div></blockquote></div></div>      </div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="dare-need-ought-to-and-used-to-semi-modal-verbs"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title"><i class="i">Dare</i>, <i class="i">need</i>, <i class="i">ought to</i> <i class="i">and</i> <i class="i">used to</i> (semi-modal verbs)</h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Dare, need, ought to</i> and <i class="i">used to</i> are <span class="target"/>often called semi-<span class="target"/>modal <span class="target"/>because in some ways they are formed like modal verbs and in some ways they are <span class="target"/>like other main verbs.</p><p class="p">Like modal verbs, <i class="i">ought to</i> and <i class="i">used to</i> do not change form for person. <i class="i">Needn’t</i> and <i class="i">daren’t</i> do not have a third person <i class="i">-s</i> in the present:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">It <b class="b">used to</b> be so easy. It <b class="b">ought to</b> be easy now.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">She <b class="b">needn’t</b> worry.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">John <b class="b">daren’t</b> tell Ruth about the accident.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">Like main verbs, the negative form of <i class="i">need</i>, <i class="i">dare</i> and <i class="i">used to</i> is made by using <i class="i">do</i>. But it can also be made without using <i class="i">do</i> (like modal verbs).</p><div class="panel pad-indent"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title">Compare</span></div><div class="panel-body pad-indent"><table class="table"><span class="colgroup"><col class="col"/><col class="col"/></span><tbody class="tbody"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">You <b class="b">don’t need to</b> dress smartly.</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">You <b class="b">needn’t</b> dress smartly.</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We <b class="b">don’t dare (to)</b> tell him.</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We <b class="b">daren’t</b> tell him.</i></p></blockquote></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><p class="p">The negative form of <i class="i">ought to</i> is not made with <i class="i">do</i>:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We <b class="b">oughtn’t to</b> spend so much money.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">We don’t ought to spend so much money</s>.</p></blockquote><p class="p">Like main verbs, the question form for <i class="i">need, dare</i> and <i class="i">used to</i> is made by using <i class="i">do</i>:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Does</b> she <b class="b">need</b> to get a camera before she goes away?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Did</b> you <b class="b">use to</b> play football when you were a child?</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">Question and negative forms of <i class="i">ought to</i> are rare.</p><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/dare"><i class="i">Dare</i> </a> </p></li><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/need"><i class="i">Need</i> </a> </p></li><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/ought-to"><i class="i">Ought to</i> </a> </p></li><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/used-to"><i class="i">Used to</i> </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div></div></div></article>
</div>
</div>
<div class="clrd">
<div class="mod float-xl">
<div id='ad_btmslot_a' class='am-default '>
</div>

<li class="section">
<a>Easily confused words</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/above-or-over"><i>Above</i> or <i>over?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/across-over-or-through"><i>Across</i>, <i>over</i> or <i>through</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/advice-or-advise"><i>Advice</i> or <i>advise</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/affect-or-effect"><i>Affect</i> or <i>effect</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/all-or-every"><i>All</i> or <i>every</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/all-or-whole"><i>All</i> or <i>whole</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/allow-permit-or-let"><i>Allow</i>, <i>permit</i> or <i>let</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/almost-or-nearly"><i>Almost</i> or <i>nearly</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/alone-lonely-or-lonesome"><i>Alone</i>, <i>lonely</i>, or <i>lonesome</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/along-or-alongside"><i>Along</i> or <i>alongside</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/already-still-or-yet"><i>Already</i>, <i>still</i> or <i>yet</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/also-as-well-or-too"><i>Also</i>, <i>as well</i> or <i>too</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/alternate-ly-alternative-ly"><i>Alternate(ly)</i>, <i>alternative(ly)</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/although-or-though"><i>Although</i> or <i>though</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/altogether-or-all-together"><i>Altogether</i> or <i>all together</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/amount-of-number-of-or-quantity-of"><i>Amount of</i>, <i>number of</i> or <i>quantity of</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/any-more-or-anymore"><i>Any more</i> or <i>anymore</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/anyone-anybody-or-anything"><i>Anyone</i>, <i>anybody</i> or <i>anything</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/apart-from-or-except-for"><i>Apart from</i> or <i>except for</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/arise-or-rise"><i>Arise</i> or <i>rise</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/around-or-round"><i>Around</i> or <i>round</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/arouse-or-rouse"><i>Arouse</i> or <i>rouse</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-or-like"><i>As</i> or <i>like</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-because-or-since"><i>As</i>, <i>because</i> or <i>since</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-when-or-while"><i>As</i>, <i>when</i> or <i>while</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/been-or-gone"><i>Been</i> or <i>gone</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/begin-or-start"><i>Begin</i> or <i>start</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/beside-or-besides"><i>Beside</i> or <i>besides</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/between-or-among"><i>Between</i> or <i>among</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/born-or-borne"><i>Born</i> or <i>borne</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/bring-take-and-fetch"><i>Bring</i>, <i>take</i> and <i>fetch</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/can-could-or-may"><i>Can</i>, <i>could</i> or <i>may</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/classic-or-classical"><i>Classic</i> or <i>classical?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/come-or-go"><i>Come</i> or <i>go?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/consider-or-regard"><i>Consider</i> or <i>regard</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/consist-comprise-or-compose"><i>Consist</i>, <i>comprise</i> or <i>compose</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/content-or-contents"><i>Content</i> or <i>contents?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/different-from-different-to-or-different-than"><i>Different from</i>, <i>different to</i> or <i>different than</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/do-or-make"><i>Do</i> or <i>make</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/down-downwards-or-downward"><i>Down, downwards or <i>downward?</i></i></a>

<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/during-or-for"><i>During</i> or <i>for?</i></a>

<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/each-or-every"><i>Each</i> or <i>every</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/east-or-eastern-north-or-northern"><i>East</i> or <i>eastern</i>; <i>north</i> or <i>northern</i>?</a>

<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/economic-or-economical"><i>Economic</i> or <i>economical</i>?</a>

<li class="section">
<a>Words, sentences and clauses</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-words-clauses-and-sentences">about words, clauses and sentences</a>
</li>
<li>

<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/comparing-and-contrasting">comparing and contrasting</a>

</li>

</li>
<li>

</li>

</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/so-and-such"><i>so</i> and <i>such</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/word-formation">word formation</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/word-order-and-focus">word order and focus</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>Using English</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/discourse-markers">discourse markers</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/emphasising-and-downtoning">emphasising and downtoning</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/functions">functions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/numbers">numbers</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/people-and-places">people and places</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking">speaking</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/types-of-english-formal-informal-etc">types of English (formal, informal, etc.)</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/useful-phrases">useful phrases</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/writing">writing</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>Verbs</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-verbs">about verbs</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/be-and-be-expressions"><i>be</i> and <i>be</i> expressions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/common-verbs">common verbs</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/future">future</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/infinitives-and-imperatives">infinitives and imperatives</a>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>modals and modality</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/can"><i>Can</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/could"><i>Could</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/could-may-and-might"><i>Could</i>, <i>may</i> and <i>might</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/dare"><i>Dare</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/had-better"><i>Had better</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/may"><i>May</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/might"><i>Might</i></a>
</li>
<li class="section current">
<a>Modality: forms</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/modality-forms#dare-need-ought-to-and-used-to-semi-modal-verbs"><i>Dare</i>, <i>need</i>, <i>ought to</i> <i>and</i> <i>used to</i> (semi-modal verbs)</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/modality-introduction">Modality: introduction</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/modality-meanings-and-uses">Modality: meanings and uses</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/modality-other-modal-words-and-expressions">Modality: other modal words and expressions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/modality-other-verbs">Modality: other verbs</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/modality-tense">Modality: tense</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/must"><i>Must</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/ought-to"><i>Ought to</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/shall"><i>Shall</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/should"><i>Should</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/will"><i>Will</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality/would"><i>Would</i></a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/passive">passive</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/past">past</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/present">present</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/verb-patterns">verb patterns</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div id='ad_houseslot_a' class='am-default '>
</div>
<div class="mod mod--dark mod--style2 oflow-hide">
<div class="pad">
<p class="h2 semi-flush alt">Word of the Day</p>
<p class="h4 feature-w-big wotd-hw">taro</p><p>a tropical plant that has a root that is cooked and eaten</p>
</div>
<div class="txt-block txt-block--alt with-icons js-eqh-sticky">
<div class="with-icons__content">
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/taro" class="a--rev a--b">
<span>About this</span> <i class="fcdo fcdo-angle-right" aria-hidden="true"></i>
</a>
</div>
<div class="with-icons__icons">
